ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a deeper knowledge about African American identity and the historical context that has shaped America and its perception of African Americans.

I learned how to think critically about academic texts and read for substantial information, not just surface level reading. I came to new conclusions about African Americanness  what it means, who fits the definition, who does not, what benefits does that definition bring? It was interesting to question my previously held beliefs and try to put myself in conversation with other authors.

I gained key knowledge on African American history and a deeper understanding of my identity as a Black American. I also improved my critical thinking and writing skills through insightful class discussions and writing workshops.
I learned what it means to be an African American, the difference between race and ethnicity, the double consciousness that African Americans have, and so much more.

This course has helped enhance my reading and writing skills. I have learned to annotate while reading, and I also learned how to write a stronger analysis. This course has also helped to build my confidence when speaking publicly.

Oh I learned so much. So much about being Black/African American and how important it is that we understand the difference between the labels that we have. The course had a good balance of readings from both the past and the present, so I learned about how African Americanness has changed throughout the nation's history and what the consequences are of having/not having the label of "African American." I learned that the definition of "African American" is complex and that we probably will never come to a consensus on what the term means and who it includes and excludes. And I learned about where the term originated.

I learned many different perspectives on the definition of the identifier "African American," considered the implications of this name/label, and learned plenty about African American identity and history.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No weaknesses that I can think about. A strength is an intimate size class and a teacher that creates a open environment for the students to share ideas.

2 strengths were the amount of discussion and collaboration in the course. We always had opportunities to ask our peers for ways to improve and help each other with our writing and critical thinking. This kept me much more engaged in the course than if I had just been watching a lecture. There were not many weaknesses in the course that I can think of  our readings were interesting and relevant, our coursework was manageable, and Professor Smith was extremely available and helpful to us all.

Strengths: engaging readings, manageable workload, excellent discussions, detailed instructor feedback, and Professor Smith was flexible about extensions and offered extra credit
Weakness: I would have liked a little more in-class writing practice.
The texts we read are great and the teacher is very compassionate and caring.
This course ran smoothly throughout the semester. Professor Smith is amazing.

Strengths - the reading was interesting, the papers were chunked into manageable pieces, the small size of the class lent itself to interesting and engaging conversations, the extra credit
Weaknesses - Seeing no improvement in my grade from the second paper to the third paper (big research paper) was kind of disheartening, as I put in lots of effort to apply the corrections from the second paper. it made me wonder whether my writing actually improved

I thought the texts we read were extremely interesting and thought-provoking. The only weakness I can think of would maybe be to vary what we do in class more  we had the same type of discussion almost every class, occasionally doing different exercises and activities. I enjoy the discussions and have no problem with them, but it could be more interesting/get more people to participate if we did some of those exercises and activities more.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a virtual class so everything was on zoom and on canvas which was helpful.

Our class was heavily discussion based, so our small class size lent itself to this Zoom platform. We had to raise our hands before speaking, so that helped to facilitate participation, even though discussions over Zoom can be difficult. I did not face any major issues with this course in a virtual classroom setting.
Everything was great!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to any student because of how much I learned and the depth of that knowledge. I also gained a lot of writing skills and techniques that are applicable to multiple disciplines.

Absolutely, it is a great learning experience for any student who wants to improve their writing and make sure that they have the basic foundations of writing mastered. Additionally, while improving your writing, you can engage in fascinating discussions about racial identity, politics, economics, and history with your fellow classmates. It was a great opportunity to get to know my peers better and share a part of myself with them.
Yes! Whether or not you identify as African American, this class truly pushes you to be a better writer and thinker.
Yes.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone seeking to improve their writing skills. Also, to anyone interested in learning about African American history.

Yes, my favorite class at Yale so far. I learned things in this class that I think are actually important to current events at Yale and beyond. I'm not the biggest fan of writing papers, but because the subject material was interesting, writing the papers was not that painful. We talked about very interesting and monumental material, and I'm leaving this class with a newfound interest in Black Studies and also with better writing skills.

Absolutely. The texts we read are not only going to make you a more critical reader and writer, but they will likely bring entirely new insights into your life and make you consider questions you haven't before. African American history isn't taught much in high schools, and so taking this as a first-year or sophomore I think is extremely valuable. I now can't believe how many things I hadn't been aware of due to these gaps in my education. Would definitely recommend if you would like to become a much stronger writer, closer reader, and more knowledgeable and aware human being.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None

extras.title:
ENGL 114 09
        Who is an African American
